verses.text: In the fourth year of the reign of Ptolemy and Cleopatra, Dositheus, who had said that he was a priest and a Levite, and Ptolemy, who was his son, brought to Egypt the preceding Letter of Purim, which they said was genuine and had been translated by Lysimachus the son of Ptolemy, one of the residents of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the extent of King Xerxesâ€™ authority, ruling over a vast domain. The narrative context highlights the power and order established by earthly kings, setting up a contrast with the sovereignty of God (Dan. 2:37-38). The use of 'islands of the sea' references the broadness of his reign, similar to themes in Psalms about God's universal dominion (Ps. 72:8).
